results.title: To meet a challenge
results.brief_description: Aluminium is one of the most sought after metals in use today. All the stages in the manufacture of aluminium, from the mining of bauxite, the raw material, to the pressing of the metal into its final shape is depicted. As well as its mines in the Darling Ranges, Alcoa also owns refineries at places such as Kwinana and has ready access to ports to speed the finished product on its way, whether it be destined for Japan or the United States.

results.title: To live in darkness
results.brief_description: Shows the hazards facing workmen who, through carelessness or deliberate neglect, fail to wear goggles when these are necessary for safety. Deals with factory conditions.

results.title: To live and learn
results.brief_description: A film about London schools and school-children, showing the work of infant, junior and secondary schools. The film brings out the development of the children’s own personalities as well as showing teaching methods, and illustrates the wide variety of opportunities in London’s grammar and other secondary schools. Interviews with head teachers and parents are included.

results.title: To learn day by day
results.creator_credit: Video Media Production and Alex Jaye
results.brief_description: Offers advice to child care providers on appropriate strategies to facilitate the learning of basic concepts such as big, round, etc. as well as number games and colours. Provides a strategy which involves starting with concepts and moving on to comparisons. Appropriate for professional Development and personal development (Home Economics) at VCE level.

results.title: To keep the faith
results.creator_credit: Pat Kavanagh and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description: A religious documentary with commentary by Francis James. Illustrates the enormous cultural influence of the orthodox church over eastern Europe. Raises the issue of the cultural flux generations of immigrant families find themselves in.

results.title: To help them learn (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Examines the role of audiovisual media in modern education. Encourages the use of media for captivating children’s attention, offering a variety of approaches to learning, and stimulating students through meaningful experiences.

results.title: To hear or not to hear
results.creator_credit: Jeff Osment, Green Hill Films and Jill Mansfield
results.brief_description: A domestic scene is enacted twice - once from the perspective of a busy woman preparing a meal and then as seen by her partially deaf husband. Gives insights into the frustrations of both.

results.title: To everything there is a season
results.creator_credit: Bosisto Productions, South Australian Film Corporation and Brian Bosisto
results.brief_description: A general interest film exposing one of South Australia’s wildlife sanctuaries located at the Coorong. It instructively illustrates the interaction between the birds and the landscape against a backdrop of seasonal change. Of particular interest to students of the life sciences, conservationists and bird-watching societies. Narrated by John and Judith Dick.

results.title: To die for = Heaven's a drag
results.creator_credit: Gary Fitzpatrick, TDF Productions, London Lighthouse, British Screen and Peter Mackenzie Litten
results.brief_description: This comedy/drama about the impact of AIDS on a gay relationship draws on the same ‘ghostly lover’ premise as “Ghost” and “Truly, madly, deeply”. Mark, a drag performer, is HIV positive and in poor health. While he spends his last days at home preparing his own AIDS memorial quilt, his spunky young HIV negative boyfriend Simon, in denial about Mark’s impending death, cruises clubs and sleeps with other men. When Mark finally dies, Simon continues to pursue his hedonistic lifestyle until Mark returns to haunt his faithless lover. Mark’s endless beyond-the-grave pranks finally force Simon to face some long-submerged feelings and come to terms with his love and grief. While the patchy script undermines the film’s attempts to bring a comic touch to a serious subject, “To die for” offers a refreshing alternative to other films that focus solely on the horrors of the AIDS virus. Cast includes Thomas Arklie, Ian Williams, Tony Slattery, Dillie Keane.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gary Fitzpatrick, TDF Productions, London Lighthouse, British Screen and Peter Mackenzie Litten
